results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Switzerland and Copenhagen and then on to Italy. A feature of the film is the sculpture of ‘The Little Mermaid’, a bronze statue by Edvard Eriksen that sits on a rock by the waterside at the Langelinie promenade in Copenhagen, Denmark. Based on the fairy tale of the same name by Danish author Hans Christian Andersen, the small and unimposing statue has been a major tourist attraction since its unveiling in 1913.

Passengers aboard the ship also indulge in some fun dress-up style entertainment.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:42:00 on board a ship
00:00:44:00 a train station and filming from the moving train
00:00:55:00 looking into the cargo hold of a ship where we see cars
00:01:25:00 a riverside park and sculpture
00:01:53:00 a public square and clocktower
00:02:40:00 a boy on a bicycle and a Volkwagon model car in the square
00:03:29:00 a duck and ducklings cross a path in a park
00:03:55:00 a passenger barge on a river in a city
00:04:54:00 a city fountain
00:04:57:00 the sculpture of ‘The Little Mermaid’ in Copenhagen, Denmark
00:05:17:00 wooden house in Christiania, Denmark
00:05:39:00 filming from a train
00:06:09:00 rail crossing over a road and pretty station
00:06:20:00 examples of 1960s European cars
00:06:40:00 shipping
00:06:59:00 horse and carriage rides in an Italian city
00:07:17:00 fountain in a piazza
00:11:50:00 views of what could be the port of Naples
00:12:10:00 train travelling by the camera
00:12:18:00 view from a ship deck
00:12:42:00 shipping in a harbour
00:12:55:00 a town built dramatically into the mountain behind it
00:13:10:00 small boats laden with gear or cargo
00:13:48:00 passengers dress up for a costume party on board their ship
00:14:30:00 ships and boats in a port harbour

results.title: Show me English: the local council [episode 6]
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, David Ferris, Trevor Lunn and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: A series of programmes which aim to help adult migrants communicate in everyday situations. results.title: Looking at Puffing Billy
results.brief_description: An enthusiasts video production about the Puffing Billy railway beginning with a brief history of the line, its relatively recent retoration, and the work of the Puffing Bily Preservation Society. We are taken on a detailed trip along the line from Belgrave to Emerald Lake.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 28]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a ‘Walkabouters’ trip to the Werribee National Park in Victoria. As well as the landscape, wildflowers and insects that Wallace always likes to film, there are scenes of the campsite, pitching tents and preparing food on open fires as well as gas campstoves. A visit to Blackwood Pottery is also included where Wallace shows the mesmerising process of pottery being made by hand at a pottery wheel.

Originally made on Super 8mm film. The film has a soundtrack of music and Wallace’s narration but the quality is not good. The sound drops out early in the film for several seconds and is a little hard to understand at times.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘The Walkabouters’, ‘Werribee Gorge Nov 1972’
00:01:13:00 putting up camping tents
00:01:37:00 taking a break at a picnic table near a campfire, possibly drinking wine from wine flagons
00:01;53:00 cooking sausages on a barbeque iron plate over the open flames, sitting in 1970s style folding chairs
00:02:02:00 an old utility style truck with participants packed in the back as other participants set off walking
00:02:38:00 assisting each other as hikers are traversing a rocky creek and bending under the barbed wire of a farm fence while others hold wire up
00:03:51:00 using cameras and binoculars while listening to a guide or club member talking about the Gorge, followed by precarious crossing over water by using an old fallen tree
00:04:50:00 views around the landscape
00:06:05:00 hikers rest among the trees
00:08:10:00 views around the landscape and from a higher vantage point down to the river and tents
00:09:16:00 getting rock samples
00:09:50:00 views of the Werribee River and the rocky steep banks
00:10:15:00 views along the river, rocky outcrops and trickling waterfalls
00:11:09:00 preparing a meal back at base camp
00:12:12:00 eggs and bacon cooking on the open fire and a view of the tents
00:12:49:00 clambering over a farm gate
00:12:58:00 horses and cows
00:14:12:00 a colourful bug on a leaf
00:15:12:00 soaking tired feet in the creek
00:18:40:00 sign for ‘Blackwood Pottery’ followed by the pottery studio
00:19:15:00 views around the studio and potters at their wheels
00:20:15:00 the pottery kiln
00:21:31:00 an old cement camp fireplace barbeque with billies boiling and meat cooking
00:21:49:00 serving the billy tea at a park picnic table
00:22:08:00 eating the barbequed chops in bread, sleeping under a tree and photographing the scenery
00:23:53:00 close-ups of wildflowers
00:25:17:00 outdoor eating back at the tents
00:25:26:00 canoeing down the river
00:26:09:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: [Remix: ACMI Collection]
results.brief_description:
“Some of the thousands of stories in our collection.” This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to the gems in the ACMI Collection. A remix of home movies and short works from the collection featuring children and families, fashion models, road trips, city streets and swimming pools.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Boort Historical Society, Tony Agapitos, Jenny & Owen Peake, John Richardson, Karen Wootton, Daniel Scharf, Frank & John Straford, Ivan Gaal and The Gadsden Family.

results.title: STD's . . . Not just long distance phone calls
